snippet: An experiment involving a woman incapable of experiencing fear because of brain damage suggests a different path for signals generated by internal bodily stress like heart attacks.
abstract: Study published in journal Nature Neuroscience finds that feeling of anxiety is produced through a different brain path than fear, which is generated in amygdala of human brain; researchers identified differences by studying individuals with damaged amygdalas, who were unable to experience fear, but still felt anxiety when scientists triggered panic attacks.
lead_paragraph: An experiment involving a woman incapable of experiencing fear because of brain damage suggests a different path for signals generated by internal bodily stress like heart attacks.

headline.seo: Study Discovers Internal Trigger for the Previously Fearless
headline.main: Study Discovers Internal Trigger for Panic Attack in the Previously Fearless
